paper_abstract: We study biased Maker/Breaker games on the edges of the complete graph, as introduced by Chvatal and Erdos. We show that Maker, occupying one edge in each of his turns, can build a spannng tree, even if Breaker occupies b < (1 - o(l)) . n/In n edges in each turn. This improves a result of Beck, and is asymptotically best possible as witnessed by the Breaker-strategy of Chvatal and Erdos. We also give a strategy for Maker to occupy a graph with minimum degree c (where c = c(n) is a slowly growing function of it) while playing against a Breaker who takes b <= (1 - o(l)) . n/In n edges in each turn. This result improves earlier bounds by Krivelevich and Szabo. Both of our results support the Surprising random graph intuition: the threshold bias is asymptotically the same for the game played by two "clever" players and the game played by two "random" players. (C) 2009 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. Random Struct. Alg., 35, 431-443, 2009
paper_title: Asymptotic Random Graph Intuition for the Biased Connectivity Game
